/COMMIT_MSG.message: Regarding the response, I think ideally we'd want to have this be versioned (maybe similar do how we do the metadata API, simple datetime based version?) in case we need to evolve the response content in the future. Do you think versioning would be difficult to add?

I think we are *not* going to want to require any auth for health checks. Instead, dansmith had an idea on a way we could lazily populate a healthcheck-cache during normal auth'ed requests from users, and then check only the cache when /healthcheck is hit (that way no slow performance for healthcheck queries).

I'll ask Dan to come take a look at this patch and maybe we can work out how he could add caching to what you've got here.
that will be great. I will wait for Dan idea.

One way out of this is to add a periodic task to the api worker that uses the RPC (and the DB) so that we always have traffic. However a periodic task might be problematic from wsgi deployment perspective.

> So to summarize the way forward:
 > * Look into oslo_messaging to get info about bus connectedness to
 > avoid only getting MessageTimeout _after_ the connectivity to the
 > bus is restored.

This isn't what I'm suggesting. Doing this would change our (and presumably other projects') behavior a bit by not retrying the connect/send forever, which probably isn't desirable. What I meant was some sort of thing we can check directly from the healthcheck. Something like "hey o.msg, how many connection pool workers have active connections?". If it's more than zero, then we are likely good. Changing the retry-connect-forever behavior just so we can record timeouts ourselves would also work, but it's a lot more change.

Yeah, we don't have periodics for api workers now, and I definitely don't want to add them, especially to generate traffic on an already busy message queue. This is why we don't have service record updates from api workers either. Using CERN as an example, every api worker process would need to check connection to >70 rabbit brokers periodically, which is ... quite icky.

So to summarize the way forward:
* Look into oslo_messaging to get info about bus connectedness to avoid only getting MessageTimeout _after_ the connectivity to the bus is restored.
* Record MessagingTimeout as fault, but only report unhealthy status after a configurable amount of successive faults.
* Investigate how to detect DB faults in a generic way.
* Make the DB health and the message bus health two separate checks to allow configuring nova to report healthy status if the message bus is down but the DB is up. I.e. still server DB only request.

Just to be clear, I *do* recognize your finding there. This is why we said above that it sounds like we might need an *external* indication of connected-ness from oslo.messaging to implement that in a useful way (which may or may not exist today). Also, your point about never being able to recognize a failure is only true when we can't _connect_ to the bus. If we can, and we have something fail like we make a call to conductor and it never replies, then we *will* get the usual timeout error and could use that to factor into our decision that "Hmm, maybe we're on the wrong bus". But again, calling that a total failure would impact our ability to service DB-only requests.

+1 to keeping this simpler and defaulting to OK and avoiding periodic tasks. A bit more detail below:

+1 to returning OK if we don't know anything and FAIL only if we know we have failed a recent attempt to contact a cell DB or MQ. I'm thinking maybe we could also have a threshold for FAIL like 3 failures in a row before switching to FAIL. And any success resets the FAIL flag to OK.

Soft -1 on connection-to-rabbit status from o.msg (if it exists) because of the complexity for operators in a maintenance scenario as described by Dan.

+1 to the reset to OK if the last FAIL was sufficiently in the past (time delta of elapsed time since flag set).

If we don't want to generate our own healthcheck traffic then I think we should never send Unknown as a health check result. This just externalize the decision about or health to the caller, harpoxy. If we know that the only way to figure out our health is to get some normal traffic then just report OK and it will result in such traffic so we can get out of the unknown situation. (We can state in the response message that we are not sure about the health but the 'available' boolean [1] should be set to true).

Then the question goes back to when should we report that we are unavailable. 

My original thought was that if there is a recent unsuccessful request then we should report that we are unavailable. (And as far as I see this is the agreement above as well). For the message bus case we cannot implement that. As I commented before:

"
I looked into the RPC part of this a bit today. I simply killed the rabbit process to trigger an error for a POST servers/{serverid}/remote-consoles REST request. The message bus connection does happen at the call() method call, but that call does not raise an exception back if the connection fails. Oslo messaging retries the call forever (at least in devstack with default config). Eventually the http client timeouts but the server side doesn't. I saw the same for cast() method too. 

When I started the rabbit then the nova RPC call() returned an oslo_messaging.exceptions.MessagingTimeout exception to the nova code. 
" // PS1 Oct 2.

Based on this behavior we cannot record failed RPC messages as the failure only reported back to nova code _after_ the message bus is recovered. 

We can only record the successful RPC messages but from that information we can only deduce OK, or Unknown state (and we represent Unknown with OK). 


[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/731396/2/nova/api/openstack/healthchecks/api_service.py@55

> is not it deadlock? haproxy would not send any request until
 > healthcheck return OK and healthcheck does not return OK until the
 > first request (successful request).

Yeah, I think a few things are getting confused here, so let me try to lay out some logic that I think makes the most sense:

If we don't know anything, we should probably return OK until we know otherwise, so that we don't seal off our ability to use the API to recover from some failure or take actions during an upgrade. The API can still be useful for recovering from a failure scenario even if rabbit is disconnected, if we're doing something like updating aggregates or flavors during an upgrade or maintenance window. This activity doesn't require access to the message bus.

If we can get some sort of connection-to-rabbit status from o.msg, then maybe that would be good to query and report synchronously in the healthcheck, but it would preclude the above and require an operator to disable that, force the worker to look healthy, or start up a separate API worker for maintenance work.

I think the only time we want to really return a failed healthcheck for mq-related issues is if we have failed to make an RPC call recently, incidental to a real request, then we can return FAIL in that case to indicate that maybe we're connected to rabbit, but the wrong rabbit, etc. Since this should be "recent" it means it should time out and start to claim "I assume healthy" after some timeout has passed, which makes it auto-heal, instead of requiring some api-resident polling loop to go back to healthy.

is not it deadlock? haproxy would not send any request until healthcheck return OK and healthcheck does not return OK until the first request (successful request).

we can convert these NOT OK to Unknown status which ends up healthcheck will only be beneficial to know when things are up (safe to call) but not otherwise. 

This could have ok for first or after-interval request where haproxy can try sending the request in Unknown status but if it does not return the failure status at all then what is the benefit healhcheck? haproxy or any other LB end up either sending requests all the time even API worker is down which is no improvement from the no healthcheck situation. or not sending the request for Unknown status which is not good as In Unknown status things can be up.

FWIW I had in mind the last scenario Dan describes here, where an RPC call/cast fails with a oslo_messaging.exceptions.MessagingTimeout, that's the typical kind of RPC failure I have seen. This can happen in an environment where there are "intermittent" issues like this but not a total failure, so that's why I was thinking about a counter for how many times something Bad happens before we call it NOK. Same thing with DBConnectionError and similar.

Based on this, IMHO, it sounds like the best way forward here would be to:

(1) Prune down this patch to be only a NovaAPIHealthCheck plugin that uses a CELL_LAST_SUCCESS type mechanism to cache healthy/not healthy and return only OK or NOT OK.

(2) Move the nova system health checks into separate plugin(s) that are intended to live at different endpoint(s) and use versioning if their format is intended to be expanded in the future

Thanks for confirming that gmann.

Based on this, I'd say we should set detailed=False and I think that would actually work well in conjunction with the idea of scaling back this PoC to be a health check only of an API worker as described in Dan's comment.

We could simplify things a lot, have only one plugin that accesses CELL_LAST_SUCCESS unauth'ed and returns OK or NOT OK without any more details.

I think the thing that gives me pause is the idea of adding another endpoint to do a full system check vs using this one to do it. I want to ask penick for his opinion from an operator perspecive. I'll ping mnaser and belmoreira for their thoughts too on what they expect from /healthcheck and whether a full system check is best as a separate endpoint or same endpoint.

it seems it does expose the platform info, i run the API and got the same[1].

[1] L74 - https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/nova-healthchecks

This healthcheck isn't intended to be beneficial to the user. It's not really even intended to be useful to the administrator. It's intended to be useful to the loadbalancer or k8s system to know whether this one thing is dead or not. By combining the simple "is this one service worker healthy or not" with "is the whole nova system healthy, including rabbit and mariadb" things that are looking at the result of thus will make bad decisions, such as restarting all API workers continually until it hits some threshold, all because rabbit has become wedged.

As I said in this review as well as in the discussion in the PTG, we can make statements about the health of the larger system by looking at all the pieces, but that is (a) not what this is for, and (b) currently possible with the existing admin-focused APIs we already expose. If we mix the two purposes, we get a healthcheck API that does not serve the need of a loadbalancer/k8s, which is a quick, unauthenticated check of the health of this one service that can be called with relatively high frequency and low impact.

nova/api/openstack/healthchecks/db_healt.message: So, imagine a (real) case where I have four remote sites with compute nodes over a VPN. They sometimes come and go because they're remote and their connection is not perfect or I take one of the intermediate networks down for maintenance which causes packets to drop into a hole. This will take however long to time out, and stack sequentially if there are more than one. How long is the healthcheck timeout of the thing looking to nuke this API worker if it doesn't respond? Since all of my API workers will fall into the same trap, what will happen? Isn't the point of the healthcheck really to signal that this API worker is healthy? The status of the remote cells doesn't really mean anything about this API worker, yet there's a good chance that we'll signify that those health statuses are fatally linked.
that is good point. I was expecting timeout things on oslo middleware side but it does not seem to. But this is one thing to add.
IMHO, this again allows an attacker to do too much to load the system. And if we do, we'd need a query that is very fast and limited in size.
yeah, I agree. i think no query is ok here and just return based on connection established.

We cache these in all the API workers so we don't have to look them up each time. I definitely don't think we should make this *more* heavyweight. It does mean than adding a new cell will go unnoticed for some amount of time, but that's the same for the whole of the API, and adding cells is exceptionally rare (an order of magnitude or two less than adding nodes). People already have to HUP their APIs to notice.

nova/api/openstack/healthchecks/services.message:
In the CERN case, you've already iterated 70 cells twice for the previous two checks, and are now going to iterate >10k nodes here. On each unauthenticated request to /healthcheck. That seems extreme to me.

Also, again, I don't think the healthcheck is really supposed to report on the health of the entire system, right? Isn't the point of the healthcheck to tell the loadbalancer or k8s that this one API endpoint is not healthy and should be restarted or excluded?

> I agree on those points, For auth things, I am waiting for your
 > idea of making it with auth from cache or something.

I don't have anything super specific, other than that general concept of updating stats generically on authorized requests and returning them in the health checks. Here's one concrete thing we could try:

In context.target_cell() we yield the targeted context for the cell-targeted work we're going to do. We could change that bare yield to something like:

     yield cctx
     CELL_LAST_SUCCESS[cell_mapping.uuid] = time.time()

That way nearly everything we do that involves talking to cells will go through that, and only update the timestamp of the last success with that cell if we don't raise in the child scope of the yield. Perhaps we should also record whether or not the last attempt succeeded or failed due to an MQ or DB error. Then in the health check, we can synthesize some health going based on what we know about the last thing we tried to do. If there are no requests at all for a long time, we could report success when indeed things are unhealthy, but as soon as a request comes in and fails, we'll report unhealthy and the actor can take action.

 > For other parts, my idea is to give the health check for complete
 > system also. But enabling that by default is really heavy things as
 > you mentioned.

Well, again, I'd like to hear from people that they really expect this to be a systemic health report and not just that of the API worker. I'd rather implement systemic health somewhere else, where we can just require auth and keep these lightweight unauth'd checks purely to the health of the individual worker being checked. In past discussions about this the plan was to even implement a tiny http server on nova-compute so that we could check the health of it from something like k8s or whatever and that would definitely fit with my understanding about how these are to work.

> If we combine the three cell plugins into one then we can save the multiple iterates over cell. The only disadvantage is people would not enable those separately like if I want to enable DB health checks only then it would not be possible.

Can that be made configurable? So we'd iterate only once, and depending on what checks are enabled in the config, verify those things for each cell? Or does middleware not have that kind of config flexibility?

> Can that be made configurable? So we'd iterate only once, and
 > depending on what checks are enabled in the config, verify those
 > things for each cell? Or does middleware not have that kind of
 > config flexibility?

We don't need configurability in the middleware, as we provide the code and can check our own config.
thanks Dan, CELL_LAST_SUCCESS is really good idea and may be we can introduce it with configurable time to know how old that cache info is and refresh in healthchecks if needed.

Not, IMHO. If no requests are coming in to refresh the cache, then there really isn't much point in saying that the service isn't healthy enough to perform it's job. As soon as a request comes in that can't be satisfied due to something being unreachable, the health check would start to fail. I don't really see any reason not to just let that push the healthcheck results.

ok my concern was healthchecks saying it is healthy but when request comes and fail then healthchecks result become false info but yeah if no request for long time or no request started then we can say system is just ideal and healthchecks also not needed?

+1 to Dan's points here about the health check being an API worker health check. I have the same interpretation and I like the idea of the CELL_LAST_SUCCESS.

The initial proposal was an extremely simple "reply 200" that was simply telling that wsgi was working, which is the same thing you get when you visit /. An API worker can't fulfill requests if it can't talk to the DB and MQ, so those were identified as things to include in the health check.

And we can do that using Dan's suggestion of building a DB/MQ health cache in the background that piggybacks on auth'ed requests by end users. That way, when the load balancer calls /healthcheck without auth, all we have to do is check the cache and return OK or NOT OK.

> Well, again, I'd like to hear from people that they really expect
 > this to be a systemic health report and not just that of the API
 > worker. I'd rather implement systemic health somewhere else, where
 > we can just require auth and keep these lightweight unauth'd checks
 > purely to the health of the individual worker being checked. 

If we can keep the systemic health report function, that will be good for use, AFAIK, most administrators want to receive the alarm information automatically reported by the system, so that they can monitor the status of the platform in real time. It would be very friendly if we could keep such an excuse.

I agree on those points, For auth things, I am waiting for your idea of making it with auth from cache or something.

For other parts, my idea is to give the health check for complete system also. But enabling that by default is really heavy things as you mentioned.

Let me refactor it and divide into API vs cell based plugins instead of DB/MQ and services. What I can do is:

1. default healthchecks: very lightweight with only check API worker only. It can be used for the load balancer.

2. provide new plugins for cells, which can be disabled by default and people can enable those if they need complete health of the system. it can be used for complete system health checks usage.
   - cell_db_healthchecks
   - cell_MQ_healthchecks
   - cell_service_healthchecks
If we combine the three cell plugins into one then we can save the multiple iterates over cell. The only disadvantage is people would not enable those separately like if I want to enable DB health checks only then it would not be possible.

openstackclient/api/compute_v2.py.message:
Microversion should be passed using the microversion paramter to the REST call on the underlying adapter.

However, we really need to do negotiation, which is supported in SDK.

The lastest openstack host commands (with latest openstacksdk installed ) still don't seem to respect --os-compute-api-version parameter. So I did some digging into the code path including the sdk and  osc_lib part. Totally new to how all these are chained together, but was trying my best to get things straight. Here is my take atm (which of course could be wrong) :

Unlike many other openstack compute interfaces (which use novaclient.v2.client.Client that gets api versions from the underlying adapters [1], to make API calls), os-hosts API calls are made through osc_lib.api.api.BaseAPI at the bottom [2], which would have no idea about the api_versions if not passed by using headers [3].

So I think we might still need to pass the api_versions at this level to at least make api version specification work to host-related commands.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/openstackclient/compute/client.py#L82
[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/openstackclient/compute/client.py#L92
[3] https://github.com/openstack/osc-lib/blob/master/osc_lib/api/api.py#L141

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
When people do this, they'll see messages like the following emitted to their configuration files.

  # <SYSTEM MESSAGE: <string>:1: (WARNING/2) Inline literal start-string
  # without end-string.>

This seems valid, so I suggest we either keep them or add a toggle to switch between rst-ified parsing and straight forward dumping of descriptions.

When people do this, they'll see messages like the following emitted to their configuration files.

  # <SYSTEM MESSAGE: <string>:1: (ERROR/3) Unknown interpreted text role
  # "oslo.config:option".>

I can work around by this by simply stripping the and emitting the body of the role in rst2txt, but I'm not sure if this is always such a sensible thing to do.

I think I was asking if we (already) render e.g. links_, ``literals``, etc. in the generated *html* document for config options. It looks like we do. So do we also (today, before this change) try to apply roles like :oslo.config:option: in the html config reference? I'm sure I tried that first when I started on this project, but I can't remember if it worked (and I just needed to deal with the ugliness in the text based genconfig) or not (and I had to add it first).

> Perhaps the answer here is to make this functionality opt-in via a
 > configuration setting. Projects that want to make use of real
 > sphinx-isms in their config opt help can switch it on, vet their
 > output, fix stuff, and then turn on -W to catch future violations.
 > But folks who don't care and/or are currently seriously broken and
 > don't want to fix it, don't have to.

That's what I'm thinking too. The only reason I haven't is because I'm trying to assess how likely this is. I've no idea where to even start with that.

 > But wait, am I misunderstanding? Do the HTML-ified config docs
 > already attempt to render sphinxisms? And how do those show up in
 > the sample config today? (I'm sure I knew that answer when I
 > started this whole thing, but I've slept since then.)

The Sphinx'isms are rendered in the HTML docs (i.e. docs.o.o). They're not rendered for sample configs (nova.conf.sample) generated by oslo-config-generator though. Is that what you meant?

Perhaps the answer here is to make this functionality opt-in via a configuration setting. Projects that want to make use of real sphinx-isms in their config opt help can switch it on, vet their output, fix stuff, and then turn on -W to catch future violations. But folks who don't care and/or are currently seriously broken and don't want to fix it, don't have to.

But wait, am I misunderstanding? Do the HTML-ified config docs already attempt to render sphinxisms? And how do those show up in the sample config today? (I'm sure I knew that answer when I started this whole thing, but I've slept since then.)
